Erik Wilde (@dret): Surfing the Web Concepts

(2) Summary

APIs establish a language between providers and consumers of the provided service. The more this language can be based on well-known vocabularies, the easier it is to design this language for the API provider, and to understand the language for the API consumer. Web Concepts provide a starting point for such a "shared vocabulary", and can be constrained or extended depending on API provider needs. This presentation looks at the general idea of "API as languages", provides a brief overview of the "language components" currently available via http://webconcepts.info/ [http://webconcepts.info/], and presents ways how these concepts can be tailored to address the needs of API managers and developers.

APIs are Languages Erik Wilde (@dret): Surfing the Web Concepts

(9) What is an API?

  • An API is a product
    • APIs are created and designed and developed
    • APIs have typical product lifecycles
  • An API provides access to a capability
    • The API is not the interesting thing
    • The value is in the functionality of the API
  • An API is a language
    • API users utilize API functionality by accessing the API
    • Using APIs is a conversation between service providers and consumers


APIs are Languages Erik Wilde (@dret): Surfing the Web Concepts

(10) API Design

  • APIs need to be designed just like any other product
    • Design starts with an architectural style and associated patterns
    • The style sets the framework but leaves a lot of freedom
    • Some design elements can be reused from existing APIs
    • Some design elements have to be created for the new API
  • Design works best when it reuses familiar interface concepts
    • For UI design this allows end users to make educated guesses for better UX
    • For API design the same concept of familiarity is helpful for DX


APIs are Languages Erik Wilde (@dret): Surfing the Web Concepts

Languages and Landscapes Erik Wilde (@dret): Surfing the Web Concepts

(14) SOAP: The Dark Age

  • API design was practiced relatively little
    • Developers exposed implementation internals as Web services
    • Many APIs were exposed from a shared monolithic codebase
  • SOAPy SOA promised webby nirvana without delivering
    • The main failure was the lack of focus on loosely coupled implementation
    • Evolution needs ecosystems where individuals can flourish or wane


Languages and Landscapes Erik Wilde (@dret): Surfing the Web Concepts

(15) Microservices: Enlightenment

  • The first time enterprise IT gets the Web
    • Decouple implementations for speed and agility at scale
    • Embrace diversity so that teams can focus on solving problems
  • What do microservices mean for scale and longevity?
    • Design decisions need context for the best possible products
    • Designing into the void never is the best strategy


Languages and Landscapes Erik Wilde (@dret): Surfing the Web Concepts

(16) The Middle Ground: Guide and Help

  • Create Design Guidelines [http://apistylebook.com/design/guidelines/] that teams can use
    • Ideally based on existing practice
    • Ideally continuously changed based on the evolving landscape
  • Writing as a form of communication
    • Writing guidelines forces teams to talk about design practices
    • Reading guidelines allows teams to understand the current practice


Languages and Landscapes Erik Wilde (@dret): Surfing the Web Concepts

(17) Language and Design and Culture

  • Culture emerges as a set of shared principles and patterns
    • Culture cannot be created from the top-down
    • Culture can be observed and nudged over time
  • Design culture for APIs uses shared language building blocks
    • Documenting what APIs and teams are using
    • Helping teams in the API design efforts
  • Documenting API design culture is a continuous process
    • Feedback cycle based on practice and design guidance


Web Concepts

Outline (Web Concepts)

  1. Introduction [4]
  2. APIs are Languages [4]
  3. Languages and Landscapes [4]
  4. Web Concepts [3]
  5. Example: Representations [4]
  6. Conclusions [2]
Web Concepts Erik Wilde (@dret): Surfing the Web Concepts

(19) Concepts that matter on the Web

  • Web APIs are always based on shared architectural concepts
    • Some concepts [http://webconcepts.info/concepts/] matter for interaction at the Web level
    • Each concept has a value space for sharing meaning (such as HTTP request methods [http://webconcepts.info/concepts/http-method/])
    • Specifications establishing values are created by organizations [http://webconcepts.info/specs/] (such as HTTP PATCH [http://webconcepts.info/concepts/http-method/PATCH] via IETF [http://webconcepts.info/specs/IETF/]'s RFC [http://webconcepts.info/specs/IETF/RFC/] 5789 [http://webconcepts.info/specs/IETF/RFC/5789])
  • Web concepts [http://webconcepts.info/] provides a starter set of concepts and specifications
    • Currently there are 32 concepts with a total of 738 distinct values [http://webconcepts.info/concepts/]
    • These concepts are taken from 268 specifications from 5 organizations [http://webconcepts.info/specs/]
  • Web concepts is designed to be usable along two major axes
    1. Adding or removing concepts/values to represent the organizational Web surface
    2. Adding API-level usage to link APIs and the concepts they use


Web Concepts Erik Wilde (@dret): Surfing the Web Concepts

(20) Specifications 

 "IETF": {
  "id": "http://webconcepts.info/specs/IETF/",
  "name": "Internet Engineering Task Force",
  "short": "IETF",
  "series": [{
   "I-D": {
    "id": "http://webconcepts.info/specs/IETF/I-D/",
    "name": "Internet Draft",
    "short": "I-D",
    "specs": [{
     "amundsen-richardson-foster-alps": {
      "id": "http://webconcepts.info/specs/IETF/I-D/amundsen-richardson-foster-alps",
      "title": "Application-Level Profile Semantics (ALPS)",
      "name": "Internet Draft amundsen-richardson-foster-alps",
      "URI": "urn:ietf:id:amundsen-richardson-foster-alps",
      "URL": "http://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-amundsen-richardson-foster-alps",
      "abstract": "This document describes ALPS, a data format for defining simple descriptions of application-level semantics, similar in complexity to HTML microformats. An ALPS document can be used as a profile to explain the application semantics of a document with an application-agnostic media type (such as HTML, HAL, Collection+JSON, Siren, etc.). This increases the reusability of profile documents across media types.",
      "concepts": [{
       "http://webconcepts.info/concepts/media-type/": "http://webconcepts.info/concepts/media-type/application/alps+json" }, {
       "http://webconcepts.info/concepts/media-type/": "http://webconcepts.info/concepts/media-type/application/alps+xml" }]}},{
  • specs.json (line 2-21)

Example: Representations

Outline (Example: Representations)

Example: Representations Erik Wilde (@dret): Surfing the Web Concepts

(23) Resource Representations

  • APIs need some way to represent the information that is being exchanged
    • The API style dictates the framework for the representations
    • Individual APIs always need domain vocabularies
  • Keeping track of vocabularies becomes the domain inventory for the entire organization
    • Your APIs are your EIM


Example: Representations Erik Wilde (@dret): Surfing the Web Concepts

(24) Reusing Representations

  • Using application/json [http://webconcepts.info/concepts/media-type/application/json] helps to not reinvent the wheel
  • Many core standards are horizontal in nature
  • Some domains may have vertical standards they can reuse
  • Even vertical standards often can be extended for service-specific features


Example: Representations Erik Wilde (@dret): Surfing the Web Concepts

(25) Adding Representations

  • Adding representations can be done with new values for existing concepts
    • Using media types [http://webconcepts.info/concepts/media-type/application/json] as one way of doing it
    • Using profiles [http://webconcepts.info/concepts/profile-uri/] is a lightweight way of specializing media types
    • Using XML namespaces [http://webconcepts.info/concepts/xml-ns/] is a different way of identifying vocabularies
  • It also is possible to add new concepts that are not currently part of Web concepts [http://webconcepts.info/concepts/]


Example: Representations Erik Wilde (@dret): Surfing the Web Concepts

(26) Mixing Representations

  • Parts of APIs often can be covered by vertical standards
    • Represent problem reports in APIs with application/problem+json [http://webconcepts.info/concepts/media-type/application/problem+json]
    • Represent status information about APIs with application/vnd.health+json [http://webconcepts.info/concepts/media-type/application/vnd.health+json]
  • APIs always are a mixed design of existing and new language elements
    • Using existing language elements helps understanding but constrains the design space
    • Inventing new language elements allows design freedom but is harder for API users


Conclusions

Outline (Conclusions)

  1. Introduction [4]

Conclusions Erik Wilde (@dret): Surfing the Web Concepts

(28) But What Now? Help Web Concepts!

  • Web concepts is a starting point of shared standards
    • Meant to represent ongoing developments in the global community
    • Not meant to represent individual preferences or additions or usage
  • Make Web concepts easier to use, reuse, and tweak
    • Fork Web concepts [https://github.com/dret/webconcepts] and remove unused building blocks
    • Add building blocks in the form of other standards or inhouse definitions
  • Make Web concepts easier to relate to usage information
    • Develop ways to capture and reuse concept usage for individual APIs
    • Collect and present usage across APIs to track landscape evolution


Conclusions Erik Wilde (@dret): Surfing the Web Concepts
